filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of a digital edition of forty-three pencil drawings produced by Blake during his first decade as an independent artist, 1779-1790. Drawing lies at the core of Blake's life as an artist. Pencil was his preferred medium for sketching—more flexible, less expensive, and more easily corrected than pen and ink or chalk. Preliminary work with the pencil preceded more finished work, either as separate sketches for prints and paintings or as drawings underlying water colors. Blake's nineteenth-century writings on the arts testify to his conviction that drawing was fundamental to all pictorial expression: "The distinction that is made in modern times between a Painting and a Drawing proceeds from ignorance of art. The merit of a Picture is the same as the merit of a Drawing" (*A Descriptive Catalogue*, Erdman page 549); "Let a Man who has made a Drawing go on & on & he will produce a Picture or Painting but if he chooses to leave off before he has spoild it he will Do a Better Thing[.]" (*Public Address*, Erdman page 576); "Painting is Drawing on Canvas & Engraving is Drawing on Copper & Nothing Else…& he who Draws best must be the best Artist…." (*Public Address*, Erdman page 582); "Dear Sir, excuse my enthusiasm or rather madness, for I am really drunk with intellectual vision whenever I take a pencil or graver into my hand…." (letter to William Hayley, 1804, Erdman page 757).
Blake no doubt executed a great many more pencil drawings than those extant today. Sketches were not intended for exhibition or sale; most were probably discarded, while others may have been retained only because of more developed compositions on the other side of the leaves. Even the slightest and least aesthetically ambitious drawings offer insights into the origins and earliest realizations of Blake’s designs. These first thoughts on paper often tell us more about Blake’s habits of mind, when joined by eye and hand, than more finished works. Sketches are “the first fruits of [Blake’s] imagination,” as Geoffrey Keynes states in the introduction to his *Pencil Drawings of William Blake* (1927).
The forty-three pencil drawings presented here, produced in Blake’s first decade as an independent artist, show his early debt to academic standards of precise copying and to the neoclassical emphasis on outline. The first four works may have been drawn while Blake was a student in the Royal Academy schools. Other sketches are preliminaries for some of Blake’s most important designs. Among these are the *Study for “Glad Day”, or “Albion Rose”* (Object 6), Blake’s iconic vision of the human form divine in energetic pose, and three sketches (Objects 34-36) for illustrations to *Tiriel*, the only group of finished drawings Blake composed for one of his own poems. Several sketches are early efforts at picturing events in the Bible, Blake’s main inspiration for designs throughout his life. This biblical cluster includes *The Resurrection of the Dead* (Object 10), *Samuel Presenting Saul to the People* (Object 15), and *Job’s Wife and Other Sketches* (Object 31). Other studies, such as *Ugolino in Prison* and its verso (Objects 21-22), reveal the beginnings of subjects also of lifelong interest for Blake. Only a few drawings for Blake’s illuminated books have survived, but studies such as *Sketches for “The Book of Thel”* and *A Standing and a Recumbent Figure* (Objects 37-39) offer fascinating glimpses into Blake’s methods of graphic production and revision.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

provenance.note: Inherited by Blake's wife Catherine at his death in 1827; acquired by Frederick Tatham, probably at Catherine Blake's death in 1831; the dealer Bernard Quaritch, offered in his Nov. 1882 catalogue, item 346 with 39 other works (£36), catalogue 350 of 10 Aug. 1883, item 13843, same group and price, *Catalogue of Works on the Fine Arts* of Oct. 1883, item 13843, same group and price, and catalogue of *William Blake's Original Drawings* of May 1885, no item number, same group and price; sold by Quaritch on 30 June 1886 to W. Graham Robertson; sold from Robertson's collection, Christie's, 22 July 1949, lot 63 with four other works by Blake (£42 to the dealer Maggs Bros. Ltd.); offered by Maggs, 1949 catalogue 117 of Sept. 1949, item 498 (£35); the dealer Ernest Seligmann; sold 1960 to W. A. Caro; his daughter, Ann Caro, probably by gift or inheritance; sold by Ann Caro to the British Museum in late 1982 for approximately £3000 and accessioned by the Museum in 1983.

desc.objtitle: Sketches for "The Book of Thel": Thel and the Clod of Clay, and Thel Fleeing From the House of Clay, object 1 (Butlin 218 recto)

objnote.p: This pencil sketch is a preliminary for two plates in Blake's *The Book of Thel* of 1789. The mock-up of the plate on the left includes the design used on Bentley plate 7, but in this sketch it appears as a headpiece above the roman numeral indicating the beginning of chapter III, which begins on Bentley plate 6 in the poem. The mock-up on the right would thus presumably be for the next plate, Bentley plate 7. The design, apparently showing Thel standing in front of the "house" of the "matron Clay" (Erdman page 6), was not used in *The Book of Thel*. This rejected design lends support to the supposition that Blake originally intended a different ending for his illuminated book than the one present in all extant copies. The design, however, might illustrate the present ending of the poem when Thel flees the house of Clay (the grave) to return to "the vales of Har" (Erdman page 6). See also the sketch on the verso of this leaf, a preliminary drawing for the design on Bentley plate 6 of *The Book of Thel*.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This pencil sketch is a preliminary for two plates in Blake's *The Book of Thel* of 1789. The mock-up of the plate on the left includes the design used on Bentley plate 7, but in this sketch it appears as a headpiece above the roman numeral indicating the beginning of chapter III, which begins on Bentley plate 6 in the poem. The mock-up on the right would thus presumably be for the next plate, Bentley plate 7. The design, apparently showing Thel standing in front of the "house" of the "matron Clay" (Erdman page 6), was not used in *The Book of Thel*. In the design at left, a vignette (or headpiece) of Thel, a seated gowned woman in a contracted position with legs drawn up and arms crossed over her knees, occupies the top register above horizontal lines, indicating the position of a text, in the lower half. The larger figure below her is the "matron Clay"; the smaller figure to the left is the infant "Worm" (Erdman page 6). The composition at right contains similar horizontal lines indicating text in the upper register while the vignette (or tailpiece) below depicts Thel with outstretched arms in front of the house of Clay as three figures fly or hover above. These last figures may be Thel's "moans" which "flew o'er my [the Clay's] roof" (Erdman page 6).

component.illusobjdesc: The top half of the rectangular sketch at left depicts a vignette of Thel, a seated gowned woman in a contracted position with legs drawn up and arms crossed over her knees. Bending forward, she turns her head down; her long hair may be pulled back in a bun. She may look down at the two smaller figures on the ground in front of her.

Two smaller figures sit or recline on the ground in front of the seated female figure in the composition at left. The figure at left, who may lean against the larger figure's gown, is the infant "Worm" (*The Book of Thel*, Erdman page 6), facing forward and right with legs extended forward, toward the viewer. This figure has curly hair and is nude. Its slightly bent arms are visible by its sides, and it may look toward the second figure at right.

Two smaller figures sit or recline on the ground in front of the seated female figure in the composition at left. The figure at right is the "matron Clay" (*The Book of Thel*, Erdman page 6), a nude female figure who reclines on her side facing forward with head at left turned to look toward her companion at left. The matron Clay is also referred to in the poem as the "Clod of Clay" (Erdman page 5). She appears to have short hair. Her left arm is extended and braced on the ground while her right is raised horizontally to reach or lean forward and touch the shoulder of the infant. Her legs are extended with the left crossed over the right near the knee.

Various types of vegetation surround the three figures depicted in the top half of the sketch at left. There appear to be vines or perhaps the stems of flowers (perhaps with blossoms?) at right and additional, albeit indeterminate, vegetation at left. There may be a tall lily visible at left.

In the lower half of the rectangular composition at left, horizontal lines act as stand-ins for the lines of text that appear in later versions of plate 6 in *The Book of Thel* Above these lines is the chapter number, "III" (see the Textual Transcription).

The vignette in the bottom half of the sketch at right depicts Thel, a figure standing before a structure, as three figures fly or hover above. Thel, who may be gowned, stands or walks facing forward and to the left with one leg extended backward and arms raised between the horizontal and 135 degrees. This figure may have its hair arranged in a bun(?). Thel may be fleeing the house, much as she "Fled back unhinderd ... into the vales of Har" at the end of *The Book of Thel* (Erdman page 6). The design may be an alternative version for the tailpiece on Bentley plate 7 of *The Book of Thel*. The design published in that position is the one depicted upper left in this drawing.

The vignette in the bottom half of the sketch at right depicts Thel, a figure standing before a structure, as three figures fly or hover above. The building appears to be a one-story structure with a slanted roof and vertical posts lining both of the visible exterior walls. The figure appears to stand in an open doorway (though the door inside is not clearly depicted). The structure is probably the "house" of the "matron Clay" (Erdman page 6).

The vignette in the bottom half of the sketch at right depicts Thel standing before a structure as three figures fly or hover above. These flying figures may be Thel's "moans" which "flew o'er my [the Clay's] roof" (Erdman page 6). The highest of these figures is positioned horizontally with head at left, facing left with head up and mouth open(?). Its arms are raised at 135 degrees with fingers spread. Both legs are extended with one raised diagonally upward. This figure appears to wear clothing of some sort (perhaps a shirt and pants?) though the details of these are indistinct.

The vignette in the bottom half of the sketch at right depicts a figure entering or exiting a structure as three figures fly or hover above. These flying figures may be Thel's "moans" which "flew o'er my [the Clay's] roof" (Erdman page 6). The middle figure is positioned horizontally with head at left, facing forward, and appears to wear a gown. Its arms are bent upward and legs extended together. The figure may look down toward the standing figure of Thel below.

The vignette in the bottom half of the sketch at right depicts a figure entering or exiting a structure as three figures fly or hover above. These flying figures may be Thel's "moans" which "flew o'er my [the Clay's] roof" (Erdman page 6). The lowest of these figures is also the smallest and may be a child or infant. This figure is positioned diagonally downward with head at right, facing right perhaps to look at the standing figure of Thel below. Both arms appears to be raised horizontally and may reach toward the standing figure. It may extend one leg backward and bend one leg at the knee, though these details are indistinct.

Along the left edge of the vignette in the composition at right, a large tree is visible. Its thick trunk, which may be wrapped with vines near the base, grows up the left margin. Several short branches, perhaps with leaves, are visible at left while, at right, one sizeable branch appears to grow rightward along the upper margin of the scene, above the three flying figures. This branch produces several smaller branches that may have leaves that grow downward near the right side of the design and hang over the roof of the structure below. Alternatively, the lines upper right in this vignette may be clouds and/or background hills.
In the vignette lower right, the lines upper right may be part of the large tree growing left of the house, but might be independent motifs such as clouds or background hills.
In the top half of the rectangular composition at right, horizontal lines act as stand-ins for the lines of text; however, this plate design was replaced in the final version of *The Book of Thel*.
